'''Mohammad Salim Al-Awa''' (born 1942) is an [[Egypt]]ian [[Islamism|Islamist]] thinker, widely considered to belong to the moderate [[Islamic democracy|Islamic democratic]] strain. He is the former Secretary General of the [[International Union for Muslim Scholars]] based in London, and head of the [[Egyptian Association for Culture and Dialogue]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sabanews.net/en/news168389.htm |title=Saba Net - Yemen news agency |publisher=Sabanews.net |date= |accessdate=September 22, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2006/813/eg3.htm |title= The power of words |publisher=Al-Ahram Weekly |date=September 27, 2006 |accessdate=September 22, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Beals |first=Greg |url=http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=129550906 |title=The Root: US Debates About Islam Resonate Overseas |publisher=NPR |date= |accessdate=September 22, 2010}}</ref> Al-Awa has been called one of the few Islamic thinkers who has made a "serious attempt" at "defining what [[Islamism]] would mean in a modern society," or "courageously delved into the realities of Islamic history and experimented with new interpretations."<ref>''Egypt on the Brink'' by Tarek Osman, Yale University Press, 2010, p.107-8, 214</ref>
On 14 June 2011, Al-Awa declared his candidacy for the [[Egyptian presidential election, 2011|upcoming Egyptian presidential election]] in September of that year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/468110 |title=Islamic thinker decides to run for president |publisher=[[Almasry Alyoum]] English Edition |date=14 June 2011 |accessdate=22 June 2011}}</ref>
